context_meta.title: Texas baseball is BACK (at the Disch)
context_meta.summary: On Sunday, the Texas Longhorns held off the Indiana Hoosiers to secure the Austin Regional and a spot in the NCAA Super Regionals. The Longhorns gathered victories over Texas Southern, an SEC school, and Indiana, and celebrated their regional sweep late into the night last night. On Monday, Texas spent the day watching the Oxford Regional closely to see if a trip to Ole Miss or one more round of Austin baseball against Tennessee Tech was in its future. Now, the unknown is fact — Texas baseball is BACK (at the Disch). Tennessee Tech completed the unlikely two game day sweep over heavily favored No. 4 Ole Miss today, winning the first game 15-5 and the second game 3-2. Ole Miss came into the regional

context_meta.title: Dodgers Emailbag: A Slump Buster For Cody Bellinger?
context_meta.summary: The Dodgers have moved Cody Bellinger down in the lineup, they've tinkered with his batting stance, and rested him against both left and right-hand pitching. But have they tried everything? And by “everything” I mean a trip to the Pacific Coast League. After a 4-2 week which culminated in a rousing sweep of the Rockies in Denver Sunday, fewer questions about the Dodgers pennant chances linger on the fingertips of fans. But there is concern about L.A.'s slumping first baseman. We'll address that, chat about pitching, about the red-hot Matt Kemp, and about an Andrew Toles sighting in this evening's column, which marks the 19th in a multi-season series we call Dodgers Emailbag. context_meta.title: Red Sox's Alex Cora Explains Why Steven Wright Will Make Spot Start Tuesday
context_meta.summary: The Boston Red Sox will veer from their usual starting rotation for Tuesday's game against the Detroit Tigers at Fenway Park. Sox manager Alex Cora revealed last week that Steven Wright will make a spot start for the series opener. Wright has been strong out of the bullpen for Boston since rejoining the team May 14, allowing just four runs over 16 innings with 14 strikeouts. While some might have believed Wright's upcoming start is the start of his integration into the rotation, Cora made sure to set the record straight about his decision. “I do feel this is a time of year that, if I'm feeling it, I know they're feeling it,” Cora said, per MLB.com's Ian Browne. “With the traveling, all those

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Pitcher Jackson Kowar, Gators collapse during 7-4 loss FAU in Gainesville Regional
context_meta.summary: The biggest night of UF's pitcher Jackson Kowar's baseball career also turned out to be his worst night as a Florida Gator. Projected to be a first-round pick during the MLB draft, Kowar continued his recent struggles for the Gators during a 7-4 loss to FAU in the Gainesville Regional. The loss, Kowar's third straight, forced an elimination game late Monday night between the Gators (44-18) and Owls (43-18-1). The winner will advance to this weekend's Super Regional to face Auburn. Kowar entered the night 9-4 this season and with the best winning percentage in school history (24-5, .828). But he allowed seven runs — four of them earned — along with 11 hits and four walks on a season-high 111 pitches.

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Mets select hot-hitting outfielder with No. 6 pick in MLB Draft
context_meta.summary: The Mets bobbed while the other teams at the top of the MLB draft weaved. For the first time in 12 years, the first five picks were college players, but that didn't scare the Mets away from going with youth, a departure from their preference over the past half-decade. With two of their top choices, college third basemen Alec Bohm and Jonathan India off the board, they picked Wisconsin high school outfielder Jarred Kelenic, a potential five-tool player who has committed to Louisville if he doesn't sign a professional contract. The 6-foot-1, 190-pound, left-handed hitting outfielder is the first Wisconsin native to go in the top 10, and helped USA Baseball's 18-and-under team win gold medals each of the past two years.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Reality check about to arrive for first-place Mariners
context_meta.summary: The last time the Seattle Mariners were in first place this deep into the season, the current hitting coach was the designated hitter, the current ''Special Assistant to the Chairman'' was hitting .352 at the top of the order, and the club won 93 games but missed the playoffs. Yes, it has been a long time since Edgar Martinez and Ichiro Suzuki had the Mariners in contention like they are right now. ''We just love playing for each other right now,'' pitcher Marco Gonzales said.

context_meta.title: All Brewers fans recognize the hidden characters in the ball-in-glove logo, right? Right?
context_meta.summary: The Brewers donned their retro powder blue uniforms in the Windy City over the weekend against the Chicago White Sox, complete with the famous and much-beloved "ball-in-glove" logo that has returned to semi-regular use over the past decade. If you missed it last week, a Mets TV reporter for SNY TV, Steve Gelbs, created quite the fervor when he posted his admiration for the logo, and for the hidden letters M and B therein. (Full disclosure from the author: I wore a version of this hat all the time in high school and college but myself didn't realize the hidden pictures until a college friend casually mentioned it in class one day. I played it cool -- "Oh yeah, of course, isn't that awesome?" --

context_meta.title: MLB Draft 2018: Texas high school teammates could be first-round picks
context_meta.summary: What do Mike Moustakas, Max Fried, and Scott Kazmir have in common? Coming out of their senior years of high school they were taken in the first round of the MLB draft along with a teammate. This year, two young men from Texas have the same chance. Jordan Groshans and Adam Kloffenstein of Magnolia High, located about 45 miles northwest of Houston, could be the first pair of teammates taken out of high school since Fried and Lucas Giolito in 2012 when the MLB Draft begins Monday. context_meta.title: Yankees' ire about Sunday Night Baseball just one example of MLB's 'ridiculous' schedule
context_meta.summary: SportsPulse: MLB insider Bob Nightengale talks about timely topics, including the disappointing NL West and New York Mets. DETROIT – Aaron Boone said it was “ridiculous'' that the Yankees are forced to play a night game July 8 at Toronto, with a doubleheader at Baltimore the next day. And he's right. He is right to think that anyone who'd argue that point “is not being truthful,'' which aims at ESPN and MLB's association with Sunday Night Baseball. The Yankees, in particular, are regularly impacted by ESPN, which naturally maxes out their Sunday Night appearances - often creating more than an inconvenient travel situation, despite remaining within MLB's parameters.  Well, the owners aren't giving

context_meta.title: Power Rankings: Make way for new contenders in NL shake-up
context_meta.summary: ESPN.com Another week into the season, the same three American League powerhouses rule the roost -- and in the same order for now -- but things are getting interesting in the Senior Circuit as the National League's top teams sort out their own pecking order. This week's voting placed the Astros, Red Sox and Yankees in the top three slots -- the Astros getting three first-place votes, the Red Sox two -- but the NL's top contenders are suddenly coming into focus as fast starters fade and teams with staying power begin to make their cases. context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: MLB Draft 2018: Selection Order and Predictions for 1st-Round Baseball Prospects
context_meta.summary: The 2018 MLB Draft is set to begin Monday night with teams hoping to find the next superstars in the sport. While baseball draftees don't often make the same type of immediate impact as football or basketball, this class features several top college players who could quickly move through the minor leagues and star in the majors before too long. The high school prospects on the board also possess plenty of upside, although they might be pushed further down the draft due to uncertainty. The Detroit Tigers will select first after finishing 64-98 in 2017, but every team will have a chance to add talent to their organization on the first day of action. 2018 MLB Draft Order First Round 1. context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Former general manager expresses concern about Marlins' first-round pick
context_meta.summary: The Marlins' selection of Tampa prep outfielder Connor Scott with the 13th overall pick in the amateur draft elicited some lively debate on the MLB Network set on Monday night. MLB.com's Jonathan Mayo said Scott “reminds some people of a Christian Yelich type, and the Marlins had good success with Yelich.... Maybe they feel like he can be another that type of player.” But former Rockies general manager Dan O'Dowd, now an MLB Network analyst, said: “Not to argue, but I will. The swing path and hands on Yelich were so far advanced from this young man. The one thing you have to do when you take a kid like this is be patient. Just give him an opportunity to work his way though that issue.” That issue,
